abstract.text: An object that plays audio media items from the device’s Music app library.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Create an instance of a music player to play media items in your app. There are two types of music players:
An
application music player
plays music locally within your app. It isn’t aware of the Music app’s Now Playing item, nor does it affect the Music app’s state. There are two application music players:
and
. The application queue player provides greater control over the contents of the queue and is the preferred player.
The
system music player

employs the built-in Music app on your behalf. On instantiation, it takes on the current Music app state, such as the identification of the Now Playing item. If a user switches away from your app while music is playing, that music continues to play. The Music app then has your music player’s most recently-set repeat mode, shuffle mode, playback state, and Now Playing item.
Creating a new instance of
and not specifying the player type returns a system music player.
Only use a music player on the app’s main thread.

content.text: Accessing limited playback information while using Home Sharing

inlineContent.text: The built-in Music and Videos apps can play media from shared libraries using Home Sharing. However, third-party apps using the Media Player framework only have access to the device music library. This means that your app can’t display the title of a home-shared song in your user interface. Specifically, if the Music app is playing a home-shared song, and you’re using a system music player, the value of the
property of your music player is
. However, other playback information is available when playing shared media. For example, the framework updates the value of the
property when the system music player plays a home-shared item.

content.text: Choosing how the system handles remote control events

inlineContent.text: Users can initiate audio playback commands through an external headset or accessory.
If you use an
application music player
, the system sends these commands as remote control events to your app, but you don’t provide code to handle them. The framework receives and handles the remote control events.
If you use the
system music player

, your app uses the Music app to play audio, which means that the Music app is the Now Playing app. The Music app receives and handles the remote control events. For example, if your app plays audio using the system music player, and the user switches from your app to the iOS device’s Now Playing controls, the controls work as expected. That is, they can play or pause audio, or skip to the next and previous items.

abstract.text: Defines the `id` of a null instance.
Find and play songs, audio podcasts, audio books, and more from within your app.
A protocol that defines the interface for controlling audio media playback.
The music player playback state modes.
A media player object that you use to revise the queue that’s currently playing.
An object that plays audio media items from the device’s Music app library.
Inserts the media items defined by the queue descriptor after the last media item in the current queue.
Returns the application music player.
Returns the application queue music player.
Starts the generation of playback notifications.
Ends the generation of playback notifications.
Returns the iPod music player, which controls the iPod app’s state.
The index of the now playing item in the current playback queue.
The currently-playing media item, or the media item in a queue that you designated to begin playback with.
The current playback state of the music player.
Prepares a music player for playback.
Inserts the media items defined by the queue descriptor into the current queue immediately after the currently playing media item.
The current repeat mode of the music player.
Set the music player’s playback queue using media items that fit the queue descriptor properties.
Sets a music player’s playback queue based on a media query.
Sets a music player’s playback queue using with media items identified by the store identifiers.
Sets a music player’s playback queue using a media item collection.
The current shuffle mode of the music player.
Restarts playback at the beginning of the currently playing media item.
Starts playback of the next media item in the playback queue, or if the music player isn’t playing, designates the next media item as the next item to play.
Starts playback of the previous media item in the playback queue, or if the music player isn’t playing, designates the previous media item as the next to play.
Returns the system music player, which controls the Music app’s state.
The audio playback volume for the music player, in the range from
(silent) through
(maximum volume).
Posted when the currently playing media item has changed.
Posted when the playback state changes programmatically or by user action.
Posted when the audio playback volume for the music player has changed.
The repeat modes for the media player.
The shuffle modes for the media player.
A protocol for playing videos in the Music app.
Create a media player inside your app to play audio from the user’s media library.

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
Before a music player can produce sound, it needs a playback queue. You provide the music player with its playback queue, which specifies the media items to play.
These methods control the posting of playback notifications. You can nest calls to start or end these notifications.
